1113144655879667714.text:
What does liquidity mean? What does it REALLY mean?

I was asked this my first day on the trading desk and didn’t have a good answer. Do you?

Listen to this week’s episode of @WGMGpodcast as @Melt_Dem dive into what it means and why it’s important.https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/what-grinds-my-gears/id1450518746?mt=2&i=1000433945087 …

1112763199353307137.text: We don’t want to avoid risk altogether. Nor do we want to just be triaging after the worst has occurred. We want to have a plan to navigate risky areas in a safe way by assessing uncertainty, choosing our team carefully, and remembering to keep our eyes up and ears open.

1112762740915888128.text:
Finally, the objective of avalanche training is not to know how to avoid avalanche terrain. Nor is it to just know how to dig out of an avalanche.

It’s about how to make smart decisions when navigating avalanche terrain to ensure you don’t run into an avalanche problem.

1112762740060250120.text: Another takeaway is not to rely only on technology in an avalanche situation. Everyone’s first instinct is to reach for their beacon after an avalanche, forgetting to take in the visual and auditory clues about where a buried individual might be. This wastes time and costs lives.

1112762738994896897.text: The uncertainty framework used for assessing avalanche conditions comes in handy when selecting your team as well. If you don’t want to go into the backcountry with someone it might not be personal — it might just be that your uncertainty level about them is high.

1112762737396834304.text: Every member of the team needs to be bought into the plan ahead of time and know the decisions they will face along the way. The easiest way to achieve this is to make every member feel like they had a hand in building the plan — the IKEA effect: we like it better if we built it.

1112762736532840448.text: You’ve got to plan your outing for the team you’ve got, not the team you want.

1112762735580733441.text: The biggest factor you have to assess when heading into avalanche terrain is not the snow or the weather, but the team your with. Human factors cause the most problems.

1112762734481817600.text:
Staying alive in avalanche terrain is all about knowing your unknowns. Every assessment is defined your level of uncertainty about it.

“I have a high level of certainty that the surface snow here is weak and a medium level of certainty that the deeper snowpack is solid.”

1112762731000524800.text: So I did avalanche training this weekend. It turns out it’s a lot less about knowing how to use a beacon and a probe and a lot more about how to assess risk and make good decisions. The lessons got existential real fast...pic.twitter.com/4ofjUvMnx4
